_meta.note: Readable lore content for Guard's Journal Pages, Quest Notices, Training Manual Pages, and other narrative items. Updated for more grounded, Bethesda-style storytelling.

guards_journal_pages.text: Eastern wall showing cracks. Captain Merris ordered double watch rotation. Men are tired. Rations down to two-thirds portion. Some talk of heading back to the surface, but desertion means a flogging if caught. Better hungry than bleeding.

Supply cart didn't arrive this week. Found tracks near the grain stores - rats got through the drainage grate. Thompson's fixing it tomorrow. Haven't heard from the lower garrison in three days. Their pigeon came back. No note attached.

New posting came through. Rotating me to the eastern passages next week. Jenkins says the air's bad down there. He was there last month and can't remember most of his shift. Says he just blanked out. Doctor says it's fatigue. Maybe.
Training new guards. Farmers' sons mostly. Never held a sword. Give them the usual - check corners, watch your back in tight spaces. By week's end we'll know who has the sense for this. Half won't.

Something came through the sealed passage in sector 7. Tracks in the dust. Looked human-shaped but Sergeant Hale says the spacing's off. We resealed it this morning. Extra mortar. Captain wants it watched for a month. Just to be safe.

Heard sounds from the old chapel wing. Distant. Almost like singing. Sent three guards. They say the acoustics down there play tricks. Wind through broken windows probably. We're avoiding it anyway. No reason to go there.

Cold's getting worse in the lower levels. Ice on the walls even though we're well below where it should freeze. Miller got frostbite during patrol. Quartermaster requisitioned warm gear from the surface. Two weeks out.

Found this in my pack. Don't remember writing it. Handwriting looks like mine though. Says avoid the bell tower on the 15th. Don't know what month. Drunk me being paranoid probably. Bell tower's condemned anyway.

Someone got into the armory last night. Nothing stolen. All the weapons were rearranged though. Swords face outward now instead of in. Captain thinks it's a prank. Night shift denies it. New lock going in tomorrow.

Hayes swears the courtyard statue moved. Used to face east, now it's west. I checked the installation records - always been west. Marcus agrees with Hayes though. That's two of them. Going to report it. Might be stress or something.

Mushroom stew in the mess tonight. Thompson said it tasted off. Williams said it reminded him of his grandmother's recipe. Got me thinking about home. Six months since I've seen my family. Should write them.

North gallery ceiling came down today. Dug out the guards who were under it. Seven injured. Nobody died thank god. Found old bones in the rubble. From when this place was built probably. Sealing that section off.

Got separated from Anderson in the eastern wing. Took an hour to find him. He'd been following what he thought was my torch. We were in parallel corridors the whole time. Layout's confusing down there. We need better maps.

Found a locked chest in the old barracks. Had a key in my quarters that fit. Don't know why. Inside were assignment papers for a post that was never built. From the expansion planning phase probably. Years ago.

Someone's been watering the flowers in Captain Aldric's old quarters. He transferred out two years ago. Red primrose. Smell reminds me of pipe tobacco. Going to ask around. See who's been going in there.

Reassigned next month. Restricted sectors. They call it the Silent Watch. Less talking, more listening apparently. Long shifts. Pay's better though. Need to clear out my locker. Williams is taking over my current post.

quest_notices.title: WANTED: Thief in Cathedral District
quest_notices.text: Thefts from the Glasswork Cathedral. No forced entry. Several crystal pieces missing. Witness reports don't match up. Contact Temple Guard with information. Be careful if you find them.

quest_notices.title: URGENT: Retrieve Blade from Vault
quest_notices.text: The ceremonial sword 'Singing Blade' got misplaced in the Harmony Vault. Three years ago during inventory. Staff says they hear metallic sounds from the sealed section. Certain moon phases. Need it back for the ceremony. Vault key at administration.

quest_notices.title: CONTRACT: Archive Restoration
quest_notices.text: Lower archives flooded during spring. Water damage to the records. Some documents bled into each other. Need them separated and fixed. Priority: military records, census, land deeds. Contact Chief Archivist Pemberton.

quest_notices.title: BOUNTY: Decommission Malfunctioning Construct
quest_notices.text: Clockwork patrol unit 47 won't shut down. Last serviced forty years ago. Timer's stuck or something. Still does its patrol route through what's now residential. Wakes people up. Salvage is yours. Tools provided.

quest_notices.title: EXPEDITION: Map Eastern Corridors
quest_notices.text: Eastern wing keeps shifting. Structural settling probably. Need updated floor plans. Previous survey teams sent in conflicting maps. Maybe they used old base maps. Equipment's available. Report anything weird to Master Builder Carlson.

quest_notices.title: EMERGENCY: Bell Tower Repairs
quest_notices.text: Prayer bells in the Sunken Oratory ringing backwards at midnight. Sequence is off. Residents can't sleep. Getting disoriented. Mechanism probably needs oil and realignment. Access through west stairwell. Bring climbing gear.

quest_notices.title: COMMISSION: Portrait Recovery
quest_notices.text: Lady Ashdown's family portrait needs recovery from Crimson Gallery. Frame's water-damaged. Condensation. Gallery's restricted but family got permits. Portrait's large. Need two people to move it safely.

quest_notices.title: ALERT: Chamber Acoustics Issue
quest_notices.text: Echo Chamber having feedback problems. Water in the walls maybe. Creating weird reflections. Old recordings playing back at random. Need an acoustic engineer to look at it and fix whatever's broken.

quest_notices.title: POSTING: Apprentice for Artifact Studies
quest_notices.text: Scholar Whitmore needs an assistant. Previous apprentice transferred. Duties: cataloging, documentation, basic warding rituals. No experience required. Housing in research wing.

quest_notices.title: REQUEST: Locate Missing Explorer
quest_notices.text: Merchant's daughter Elisa went into the dungeon six months back. Last seen: eastern passages near old mining sector. She's been sending letters but the return address doesn't make sense. Family's desperate. She knows the area but might be lost or hurt.

quest_notices.title: DANGER: Structural Warning - Gilt Hall
quest_notices.text: Gilt Hall on sublevel three is unsafe. Gold leaf coating flaking badly. Samples show weird chemical makeup. Possibly toxic. Area's sealed. Don't go in without contacting the site foreman first.

quest_notices.title: INVESTIGATION: Spatial Anomaly - South Wing
quest_notices.text: South wing measurements don't match the blueprints. Ten to fifteen feet off in some corridors. Need a surveyor to remeasure. Update the records. Could be bad record keeping. Or renovations nobody documented. From last century maybe.

quest_notices.title: NOTICE: Guard Recruitment Drive
quest_notices.text: Dungeon Security needs people for eastern wing patrols. Experience preferred. Will train if motivated. Physical exam required. Background check. Long shifts underground. Apply at garrison. Reference: EAST-147.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 3: Footwork Fundamentals
training_manual_pages.text: Foundation is footwork. The Shifting Tiles exercise teaches balance on uneven ground. Recommended for new people. Some tiles in the training hall are loose on purpose. Teaches them to notice unstable footing. Common in the older sections.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 7: Combat Awareness
training_manual_pages.text: In close quarters watch for breathing patterns. Shows fatigue or fear. Check shadows for additional enemies. Opponents with strange injury patterns - be careful. Could be disease carriers. Or high pain tolerance. Either way, problem.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 11: Survival Protocols
training_manual_pages.text: Three rules for anyone down here. Don't eat preserved food older than one season. Spoilage risk. Don't enter chambers where the door frame shows forced entry. Structural issues. Don't follow voices you can't see. Acoustics play tricks in the older sections.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 15: Mental Fortitude
training_manual_pages.text: Long periods underground cause disorientation. The manual says keep a calendar. Mark your route. Hallucinations mean report to medical immediately. Could be carbon monoxide. Bad ventilation. The Void Halls have particularly bad air. Travel through quickly.

training_manual_pages.title: Appendix C: Emergency Procedures
training_manual_pages.text: If alarm bells ring thirteen times, head to safe zones. Structural failure above. Avoid doors with red paint. Plague quarantine from old outbreaks. Report strange odors to maintenance. Could be corpse flowers. They bloom near decomposition.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 5: Weapon Maintenance
training_manual_pages.text: Clean blades after every use. Blood causes rust. Rust causes failure. Check for stress fractures weekly if used often. Blades that cut unevenly have microscopic damage. Replace before it breaks mid-fight.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 9: Formation Fighting
training_manual_pages.text: Shield wall requires coordination. Trust. Keep proper spacing. Gaps are vulnerabilities. If formation breaks, rally at designated point. The drills create muscle memory that works when thinking doesn't.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 13: Armor Care
training_manual_pages.text: Inspect armor daily. Rust, cracks, wear patterns. Humidity down here accelerates decay. Unusual markings might mean acid exposure. Certain fungi. Strange patterns could be mold in the leather. Clean thoroughly.

training_manual_pages.title: Chapter 19: Advanced Techniques - PAGES MISSING
training_manual_pages.text: The Seven Forms. Forms one through three cover basic strikes. Four through six are in the sealed archives. Instructor supervision required. Form seven is theoretical. Not recommended for actual use. Injury risk.

training_manual_pages.title: Appendix F: Supernatural Encounters
training_manual_pages.text: When people report supernatural events: document everything. Check for natural causes first. Gas leaks, mold spores, carbon monoxide all cause hallucinations. If it persists, contact ecclesiastical department. They keep records of actual anomalies versus environmental problems.

scrawled_notes.text: Day 3: Shortcut through the wine cellar. Day 4: Took it again. Definitely faster. Day 5: Took longer today. Got turned around maybe. Day 6: Same route I think but ended up somewhere different. Day 7: Getting my map redrawn.

There's a merchant in the west hall selling old things. Got a locket yesterday. Reminded me of being a kid. Paid good coin. Been going back. Getting more. Can't remember why I came here anymore but the memories are nice.

WARNING - maintenance: Woman in corridor 7 offering to guide people. Not staff. Wearing old uniform from decades ago. Confused probably. Gives wrong directions. Ignore her. Use your maps. Some older guards remember her from back when but she should've retired years ago.
Marking days on my wall. Noticed some marks crossed out. Only Thursdays. Don't remember doing that. Roommate says I do it in my sleep. Should get more rest. Haven't been sleeping well.
Found a room with mirrors. My reflection moved wrong. Cheap mirrors probably. Warped glass. Thompson saw it too. We're avoiding it. Light's bad in there anyway. Makes you dizzy.
NOTICE: Stairwell to lower levels only opens Tuesdays. Lock problem. Maintenance working on it. If someone gets stuck when it closes, bell pull on third landing. Wait for rescue.

Paintings in the gallery need cleaning. Subjects look different under the dust. Several frames empty. Removed for restoration probably. One was gone yesterday. Back this morning. Should check with curator.

Tried the wishing fountain in south courtyard. Old tradition. Tossed a coin in. Interesting architecture. Makes people think about who built this. What they wanted. Easy to get distracted. Lost an hour just standing there.

Chess set in abandoned barracks. Pieces positioned mid-game. Someone's game from years ago. Left it alone. Seems wrong to disturb it. Though the pieces look like they've moved each time I pass. Foot traffic vibration probably.

Good patrol routes: Library wing. Quiet on weekdays. Kitchen. Always warm. Good for breaks. Barracks. Well-lit. Avoid mirror hall. Bad visibility. This is from old guard manual. Someone added margin notes. Can't read them but seems like advice.

pressed_pages.text: From 'Botanical Treatise': Thornvines in deep archives show unusual growth. Possibly carnivorous based on trap-like leaves. Been there for centuries according to records. Adapted to low-light somehow. Study samples need approval from head botanist.

Catalog entry 447-B: Red flowers in Thorn Archive make sounds when air moves through them. Musical almost. Care requirements: regular water, occasional fertilizer. Blood meal fertilizer produces best blooms. Standard for this type.

Research log, Dr. Holloway: Pressed page collection has remarkable historical specimens. Some species don't grow here anymore. Several from books destroyed in the fire. My assistant found pages not in our catalog. Need to cross-reference the database.

Botanist's Journal: Specimen 47. Red petals. Unknown species from northern gardens. Growth rate unusual. Three times normal. After three months it spread to seven pots. Root structure suggests aggressive spreading. Might need to isolate it.

Letter fragment pressed into page: '...trouble finding my way back. These corridors look the same. Mother if you find this I might be late. The exit signs are confusing. Walking in circles. Three others lost too. Staying together...'

Recipe card, corners burnt: 'Dungeon Bread: Stone-ground flour from eastern mill. Spring water. Knead three hours minimum. Bake till golden. Time varies by oven. Makes good field rations. Stays fresh for weeks if stored right.'

surgeons_notes.text: Patient 23: Dust inhalation from Alabaster Ward. Lung irritation. Mild calcification of extremities. Silica exposure probably. Treatment: rest, fluids, steam. Patient says feeling 'heavy'. Fluid retention likely. Watching for pneumonia. Should recover fine.

Medical observation: Dust in Alabaster Ward has high mineral content. Pulverized limestone from old construction. Prolonged exposure causes respiratory problems. Recommend masks for workers there. Several chronic cough cases. Need better ventilation.

Autopsy: Patient deceased from advanced lung disease. Years of dust exposure in quarry district. Significant calcification in lung tissue. Better safety equipment needed. Patient's last words indicated breathing difficulty. Consistent with obstruction. Recommend improved dust controls.

Surgical log, Dr. Vance: Removing crystalline growths from Patient 89. Calcium deposits. Possibly from mineral-rich water. Patient conscious and talking. Says she drinks from the eastern wells. Those wells need testing. Growth rate is concerning.

Case study: Several dermatitis cases in Marble Gallery workers. Skin hardens over time. Chemical exposure from cleaning agents used on stone probably. Recommend protective gear. Progresses slowly. Early cases recover fully with treatment and job rotation.

Medical transcript: 'Doctor I've been having synesthesia. Colors have tastes. Disorienting. I work in the dye district. Exposure to chemicals maybe. Blue dye smells strong. Purple makes me nauseous. Need to switch departments for a while.'

puzzle_notes.text: The Riddle Mill's mechanism was designed by Engineer Cogworth. Complex gears power the grinding stones. Original purpose was grain milling. Now used for training exercises. Machinery makes weird sounds. Needs oil probably. The flour it makes is just for demonstration.

Solution to Millstone Puzzle: Turn wheel counter-clockwise three times. Answer requires local history knowledge. Final step: place token in slot. Rewards are ceremonial only. Note: Mechanism's old and temperamental. Follow instructions exactly or it jams.

Lock Mechanism Treatise: Combination lock in vault uses advanced math. Each digit based on problem solving. Created by locksmith Klaus Svensson. Digit 47 requires complex geometry. Most get stuck around digit 83. Instruction manual in security office.

Cipher key from Archive: Encrypted texts use substitution cipher. Each symbol represents a word or concept not a letter. Decoding requires cross-referencing the master lexicon. Most decoded texts are old admin records. Interesting look at how this place was organized centuries ago.

star_charts.text: Astronomical notation: Reflected stars in Stargazer's Pool show unusual patterns. Don't match current night sky. Angle and underground positioning probably. Scholar Hale studied it for years. His notes say reflections show star patterns from different months. Optical illusion probably.

Navigation chart: Stars in underground planetarium are painted markers. Show safe routes through dungeon. Red star indicates treasure vaults. North star points to surface exit. Black marks show dangerous areas. Old navigation system. Still useful if you know how to read it.

Celestial observations, Dr. Vess: Constellation on courtyard ceiling rotates slowly. Mechanical device in the roof. Cycles through twelve positions for months. Paint's faded. Hard to read. Text describes safe travel times through seasons. Needs restoration.

Star map fragment: Wandering light during solstices is actually reflected torch from upper level guardian tower. Creates optical effect through the shaft. Old legend says wishing on it brings luck. Tradition mostly. Harmless fun.

cracked_map_scraps.text: Partial dungeon map. Water-damaged. Shows three corridors connecting oddly. Multiple renovation phases over centuries probably. 'You Are Here' looks like personal notation. Margin handwriting doesn't match printed text. Previous owner's notes. From a guard maybe.

Fragment of dungeon chart. Scale changes because multiple maps spliced together. Different surveyors used different measurements. Some in ink. Others charcoal. Corner note: 'Surveyed in darkness. Broken lantern. Measurements approximate. Redo this section.'

Torn floor plan. Rooms labeled with warnings: 'Singing Walls - echo chamber', 'Backwards Door - hinges wrong side', 'Mirror Hall - poor lighting'. Last room says 'Safe Room' with question marks. Someone crossed out 'Safe'. Wrote 'Needs Inspection'. Found structural issues probably.

Crude map scratched on parchment. Compass rose has five directions marked. Whoever drew this was confused about orientation. Dotted line traces a route that loops back. Bottom: 'Walked three days surveying. Got turned around. Rooms look identical. Need better landmarks. Don't trust my counting.'

Explorer's map scrap. Rooms marked with symbols. Skulls for danger. Hourglasses for time-sensitive tasks. Chains for locked areas. Doesn't match what I've found but map's decades old. Things change. Note on edge: 'Map outdated quickly. Renovations constant. Double-check routes.'

Architect's blueprint. Heavily worn. Dungeon designed with experimental geometry. Architect wanted maximum space usage. Some corridors intersect at odd angles. Staircase placement unconventional. Note: 'Client wanted max capacity in limited space. Design pushes structural limits. Recommend regular inspections.'

Survey from Cartographer's Guild: Discrepancy report. Measurements don't match between teams. Equipment calibration differences possibly. Some teams report 47 floors. Others report 4 major levels with sub-levels. Need standardized protocol. Lead cartographer retired after project. Recommend resurvey with modern equipment.

Treasure map marked with X. 'Dig here' it says. Looks like a prank. Someone doodling on official surveys. Multiple X marks all over. Bored guard during slow shift probably. Found similar joke maps in archives. People get creative during long assignments.

Topographical map with elevation markers. Odd readings. Level 1 at sea level. Level 2 reads higher despite being underground. Equipment malfunction during survey probably. Previous surveyor noted discrepancies. Recommend new survey with calibrated instruments. These old readings unreliable.

Hand-drawn map on parchment. Routes in different colors. 'Echo Corridor' noted for acoustic issues. 'Silent Hall' requires quiet for some reason. 'Forgetting Path' - nickname probably. Maybe officers called it that. Forgettable. Center shows 'Administration Office'. Standard layout notation.

old_letters.text: Dear Elena, arrived safely at my new post. Dungeon guard work's harder than expected. Corridors all look similar. Keep getting turned around. Pay's good though. Getting used to it. Think of you often. Will write again next week. -Marcus

To my family: Made it to the dungeon. Found work with mining crew. Pay's better than farmwork. Food isn't great but beats hungry. Miss everyone. Will send money when I can. Tell mother I'm eating well. -Your son

Father, sorry I left without saying goodbye. Debt collectors were getting aggressive. Didn't want trouble reaching the family. Took work in dungeon. Dangerous but pays well. Should clear the debt in a few months. Will write when I can. -Thomas

Dear Brother, expedition going well. Captain Morris seems competent. Mapped about half the eastern wing. Some areas unstable. Old construction settling. Planning to finish survey next week and head back. Food holding up. See you soon. -William

Dearest Sarah, you were right about this being dangerous. Had close call yesterday. Ceiling collapse in north passage. Nobody hurt. Makes you appreciate solid ground. Six more months on contract then coming home. We'll have enough saved for the house. -Jonathan

To the Warden: Requesting transfer to different section. Current assignment has me rotating through too many areas. Keep losing track of where I'm supposed to be. Would prefer stable posting in one wing. Getting disoriented by constant route changes. Please consider. -Previous Guard Captain

My beloved, your letter from last month finally reached me. Mail delivery's slow down here. I'm doing well. Just tired. Long shifts. Work's monotonous but safe if you follow procedures. Counting days till I come home. Miss you. -Marcus

Brother Augustine, monastery was right that this place tests faith. Lots of time alone with thoughts. Isolation's challenging. Been keeping prayer journals. Helps maintain perspective. Will finish service contract and return to order soon. -Brother Thomas

To future me: Remember to bring better boots next time. Stone floors hell on feet. Also bring more lamp oil. They never give enough. Map routes early. Don't rely on signage. Half outdated. Trust senior guards. They know the real layout.

My daughter, by the time you read this I'll have worked here twenty years. Time passes strangely. Days blend together. Kept this journal so I wouldn't forget why I came. Pay let us afford your schooling. Worth every hour. Coming home soon. -Papa

Dear Reader, I hid my savings in the dungeon before retiring. Old guard tradition. Left clues for family to find. Seemed fun at the time. Now I realize how confusing the layout is. If you're reading this and find coins, they're probably mine. Lucky find. -Retired Guard Hadley

To Explorer's Guild: Resigning from dungeon guide service. After fifteen years I need change. Work's repetitive. Lack of sunlight affecting health. Thank you for the opportunity. Will help train replacement before leaving. Best wishes. -Guild Master Petra

prayer_strips.text: Prayer for Safe Travel: 'May the path be clear and the journey swift.' Traditional blessing recited by guards before patrol. Simple ritual. Morale booster more than anything. Old tradition from when dungeon first opened. Still practiced by some older staff.

Blessing of Safe Passage: 'Guide us straight and true.' Short prayer carved into lintels above doorways. Architectural tradition from the builders. Similar carvings throughout older sections. Provides sense of continuity with the past.

Rite of Remembrance: 'Honor those who came before.' Memorial service held monthly for guards who've retired or passed away. List of names read aloud. Dignified ceremony. Names engraved on memorial wall in main hall. Good for morale to remember history.

Invocation of Protection: 'Shield us from harm, guide us from danger, bring us home safely.' Standard prayer recited at start of shift. Like a soldier's oath. Reminds everyone to watch out for each other. Simple but effective for team cohesion.

Litany of Clarity: 'Grant us clear sight and clear mind.' Popular with scholars and researchers. Helps focus before long study sessions. Also used by guards for staying alert during boring night shifts. Common enough to be almost secular now.

Hymn of the Depths: 'From darkness to darkness, in darkness we work.' Sung by old mining crews. Melancholy but honest about working conditions. Tradition carried on by some veteran staff. Reminds us we're all in this together. Working in the dark.

Supplication for Mercy: 'We are small and weak before great forces. Remember our humanity.' Used in formal religious ceremonies. Humility prayer. Standard in most traditional faiths. Written in old language but translated versions common.

Chant of Unseeing: 'What we overlook holds no power over us.' Meditation mantra some guards use to deal with stress. Philosophy being overthinking dangers makes them worse. Focus on work at hand. Don't imagine problems that aren't there. Practical approach.

Prayer of Last Resort: 'When all hope fails, when all paths close, when darkness falls, we call uponâ€”' Text damaged. Last line missing. Old prayer probably from founding era. Academic interest only. Most guards prefer simpler, complete prayers.

Devotional of the Endless Vigil: 'We watch, we guard, we maintain.' Motto of Silent Watch - elite guard unit handling restricted areas. Take vows of minimal speaking to maintain focus. Serious about security. Respected but considered a bit extreme by regular staff.
